dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so remember security tokens? Like, that huge crypto mega-trend that everyone was talking about a year or two ago, and then it just... kinda faded away?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so remember security tokens? Like, that huge crypto mega-trend that everyone was talking about a year or two ago, and then it just... kinda faded away?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Many called it the next mega-trend in crypto. Conferences sprung up entirely focused on security tokens. But fast-forward a year and a half, and progress has stalled.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, definitely. I remember thinking, 'Why would you digitize a paper document just to make it *less* portable?' It seemed a bit counterintuitive at the time, uh, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, definitely. I remember thinking, Why would you digitize a paper document just to make it less portable? It seemed a bit counterintuitive at the time, uh, you know?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The underlying idea made sense: creating digital versions of paper documents like private real estate investments and company stock would make them more portable and liquid, driving up demand.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And all these conferences popped up, but they never really delivered on the hype. But then, uh, I hear things are actually picking up again?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And all these conferences popped up, but they never really delivered on the hype. But then, uh, I hear things are actually picking up again?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But fast-forward a year and a half, and progress has stalled.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's the thing! Fast-forward, like, a year and a half, and progress has actually accelerated. We're talking over a hundred security tokens created now, according to Polymath.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's the thing! Fast-forward, like, a year and a half, and progress has actually accelerated. We're talking over a hundred security tokens created now, according to Polymath.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But fast-forward a year and a half, and progress has stalled. More than 100 security tokens have been created, according to Polymath, a startup that helps companies mint coins.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, like, where are these actually trading? Are there, uh, proper exchanges for them yet?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, like, where are these actually trading? Are there, uh, proper exchanges for them yet?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, in the U.S., there are just two main ones. Openfinance is trading four assets and seeing over a million dollars a day in transactions, which is, you know, exceeding projections. And then Overstock's Tzero has its own token trading.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, in the U S, there are just two main ones. Openfinance is trading four assets and seeing over a million dollars a day in transactions, which is, you know, exceeding projections. And then Overstock's Tzero has its own token trading.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the U.S., just two exchanges exist where these assets trade, and volume is tiny. Openfinance trades only four assets with daily transactions of less than $1 million a day, we estimate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so, volume's there. But what about regulation? I always thought that was the big holdup for security tokens. Is the SEC suddenly, like, super on board now?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so, volume's there. But what about regulation? I always thought that was the big holdup for security tokens. Is the S E C suddenly, like, super on board now?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: This is the surprising part: many of the barriers aren't even regulation-related. For U.S. companies, setting up a trading venue for these actually doesn't require full broker-dealer registration. The SEC is even, uh, *expediting* applications for alternative trading systems.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: This is the surprising part: many of the barriers aren't even regulation-related. For U S companies, setting up a trading venue for these actually doesn't require full broker-dealer registration. The S E C is even, uh, expediting applications for alternative trading systems.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Many of the barriers to adoption are regulation-related. For U.S. companies to build a trading venue for security tokens, they must register as a broker-dealer with the SEC and get a license for either an exchange or an alternative trading system (ATS), which requires a long and costly process. One crypto CEO says the SEC is dragging its feet on evaluating and granting new ATS applications to digital asset companies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Wait, really? So it's not the regulators slowing things down? What *is* then?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, really? So it's not the regulators slowing things down? What is then?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, things like cross-border trading are still tricky. Olga Feldmeier from Smart Valor points out that a global IPO with these tokens isn't as easy as you'd think. Different countries, like Switzerland versus the U.S., have different settlement systems.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, things like cross-border trading are still tricky. Olga Feldmeier from Smart Valor points out that a global I P O with these tokens isn't as easy as you'd think. Different countries, like Switzerland versus the U S, have different settlement systems.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In theory, security tokens could allow for a global IPO, says Olga Feldmeier, founder and CEO of Swiss security token exchange Smart Valor. ... But all participating nations would need to agree on a common framework. For example, in Switzerland, securities settlement can already happen on the blockchain, Feldmeier says. In the U.S., its controlled by the DTCC, a New Jersey clearinghouse that handles 90 million transactions daily.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, a New York company and a Mumbai company can't just seamlessly trade securities?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, a New York company and a Mumbai company can't just seamlessly trade securities?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Ideally with these tokens, U.S. investors could just as easily invest in a public company based in Mumbai as they could a New York company, which is far from the case today.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And then there are different views on, uh, how to even approach it. Like Dovey Wan says real estate security token offerings shouldn't be led by existing firms.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And then there are different views on, uh, how to even approach it. Like Dovey Wan says real estate security token offerings shouldn't be led by existing firms.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dovey Wan, a crypto investor and cofounder of blockchain holding company Primitive Ventures, says, A real estate security token offering should be led by an existing real estate or REIT firm, where supply inventory can be guaranteed, and demand can come from existing channels.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But then you have Josh Stein from Harbor, who, you know, he's saying 'yelling token' isn't a substitute for a good investment. Yet Harbor had a huge $20 million success.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then you have Josh Stein from Harbor, who, you know, he's saying yelling token isn't a substitute for a good investment. Yet Harbor had a huge twenty million dollars success.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In April, a $20 million security token offering led by Harbor was canceled after the participating real estate firm, Convexity Properties, couldnt get favorable terms on the loan it was using to finance the deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping] Yeah, but then, uh, the article also mentions Rhodium Capital Advisors *not* using Harbor for a big $100 million deal, so it's not all smooth sailing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but then, uh, the article also mentions Rhodium Capital Advisors not using Harbor for a big one hundred million dollars deal, so it's not all smooth sailing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Today, Stein says Rhodium Capital Advisors will use Harbor to make $100 million worth of its real estate investments available through digital tokens.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. So there's still a lot of, like, internal debate within the industry about the best way forward.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. So there's still a lot of, like, internal debate within the industry about the best way forward.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. And there are technical challenges too. Polymath's CEO thinks their old blockchain might be less secure than Ethereum, where most security tokens live now, which could hinder adoption.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. And there are technical challenges too. Polymath's C E O thinks their old blockchain might be less secure than Ethereum, where most security tokens live now, which could hinder adoption.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Polymath CEO Trevor Koverko believes his companys new blockchain will provide better security than Ethereumthe platform where most security tokens live todayand will boost adoption.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, what's the overall outlook then? Is it finally going to be the big thing, or is it still, uh, a bit of a mixed bag?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what's the overall outlook then? Is it finally going to be the big thing, or is it still, uh, a bit of a mixed bag?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Short-term, it actually seems pretty bright. Some CEOs are saying we'll be in a much better place, uh, in a year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Short-term, it actually seems pretty bright. Some C E O s are saying we'll be in a much better place, uh, in a year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The short-term outlook seems dim. A year from now, well be in about the same place, said Philippe Bekhazi, CEO of crypto trading firm XBTO, at the Consensus conference last week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But for full global adoption, where everything seamlessly works across borders, that's still a few years out?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But for full global adoption, where everything seamlessly works across borders, that's still a few years out?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Olga Feldmeier estimates one to two years for that crucial cross-jurisdictional infrastructure. But, the good news is, investors won't be waiting as long as they might like, because adoption isn't contingent on regulators making a big, slow move.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Olga Feldmeier estimates one to two years for that crucial cross-jurisdictional infrastructure. But, the good news is, investors won't be waiting as long as they might like, because adoption isn't contingent on regulators making a big, slow move.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Smart Valors Olga Feldmeier thinks it will take five to ten years to build the cross-jurisdictional infrastructure necessary for security tokens to trade across nearly every country. One thing is for sure: if adoption is contingent on regulators making a move, investors will be waiting longer than theyd like.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, a slow burn, but a boom nonetheless.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, a slow burn, but a boom nonetheless.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] Looks that way!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Looks that way!
